name: Git

name: Maven

Build and Deploy tool used for APIs
Used for API build and deploy to Apigee Edge environments on Jenkins. Not directly used by any audience. In some cases developers need to set it up for API templates.

name: Jmeter

API function and performance testing
Used for functional and performance tests. Jmeter test scripts are integrated with Jenkins jobs for auto functional test invocation. Testers use Jmeter GUI or CLI while developing test scripts.

name: Selenium

Automated Browser Testing - Dev Portal
Used for automated browser testing for Dev Portal. The invocation is done with Maven which is integrated with Jenkins for auto Dev Portal test runs.

name: Cucumber

Automated tests written in a behavior-driven development (BDD) style - Dev Portal
Used for BDD style listing of Dev Portal test cases. The invocation is done with Maven.

name: Phantomjs
description:
PhantomJS is a headless WebKit scriptable with a JavaScript API - Dev Portal
Used as headless web driver for selenium test runs for Dev Portal

name: phpcs
description:
PHP Code sniffing tokenizes PHP, JavaScript and CSS files and detects violations of a defined set of coding standards - DevPortal
Used for Dev Portal source code analysis and generated checkstyle reports integrated with Jenkins auto deploy jobs.

name: Sonarqube
description:
Continuous inspection of API code quality
Used for API code quality inspection. Currently usage is only restricted to one scrum team, Scrum-E.

name: dependency matrix utility
description:
Web application to represent and list the API dependencies and config information
A Node.js based web utility developed by Scrum-C for representation and listing of API dependencies and configuration information. Developed In-house. Not widely used by all scrums. Utlity need to be enhanced for production readiness to meet Operational and Security requirements.

name: Icinga
description:
API health monitoring tool
API health monitoring tool for production.

name: Nagios
description:
API health monitoring tool
API health monitoring and notification tools for production. And replace Nagios eventually.

name: Splunk
description:
API log and traffic analysis
API log and traffic analysis platform for production and staging Edge environment.

name: Giggle
description:
ULFF logs parser/query
Giggle is used by Operations for production issue debugging. Developed in Erlang.

name: Puppet
description:
Infrastructure configuration management
Used for ESP infrastrucre configuration management. Currently puppet modules for EP servers are uploaded on Bitbucket managed by GW team and deployed by Jenkins managed by GW team.

name: old_ops_stubs
description:
Stubs for legacy APIs and functional test
A Node.js based stubbing solution developed in-house by EP operations team. It is used for API backend mocking purposes during functional test.

name: Wiremock
description:
Stubs for backend in L&P testing
API mocking solution used during performance test. The mock responses are provided to Operations via JIRA tasks for setup. Mock responses are not centrally managed.A key driver for architectures based on microservices is independent evolvability of services. For example, when two services depend on each other, the testing process for one usually involves stubs and mocks for the other one. These can be written by hand, but as with mocking in unit tests, a framework helps developers focus on the actual test scenario. We have known of WireMock for a while but we’ve preferred running tests with mountebank. Over the past year, though, WireMock has really caught up and we now recommend it as a good alternative.

name: Swagger UI
description:
Browser for API specifications
API specification browser to view and validate the swagger json/yaml structure. Swagger specifications are centrally managed with Bitbucket.

name: Swagger Editor
description:
Editor for API specifications
Web based API specfication editor for swagger API specifications. Swagger specifications are centrally managed with Bitbucket.

name: ansible
description:
For automating individual operations tasks
Used by operations team members to automate infrastructure operational tasks. Not centrally managed.

name: iTop
description:
For CMDB
Used by operations for configuration management database for ESP servers and services.

name: Slack

team collaboration and communication
Used for team collaboration and communication. Currenly used by only Scrum-F.

aws python SDK
Boto is the Amazon Web Services (AWS) SDK for Python, which allows Python developers to write software that makes use of Amazon services like S3 and EC2. Used with python troposphere and cloud provisioing.

name: python troposphere
description:
python library to transform python scripts into cloud formation json templates
Python librabry to develop and transform py scripts to cloud formation json templates. Currently source is managed in AWS code-commit.

name: Chef DK
description:
Chef Development Kit for AWS opsworks
Used for development of AWS OpsWorks Chef recipes. Currently source is managed in AWS code-commit.

column45: Methodology that enables flexibility in prioritization and focus on quick deliverables that can be used by customersAPIGee
column57: Platform that enables fast development of websitesScrumban
column61: Scrumban is an Agile management methodology describing hybrids of Scrum and Kanban and was originally designed as a way to transition from Scrum to Kanban. Today, Scrumban is a management framework that emerges when teams employ Scrum as their chosen way of working and use the Kanban Method as a lens through which to view, understand and continuously improve how they work.CI/CD Pipeline
column65: The use of continuous delivery pipelines to orchestrate the release process for software has become a mainstream concept. However, automatically testing changes to infrastructure code isn’t as widely understood. Continuous integration (CI) and continuous delivery (CD) tools can be used to test server configuration (e.g., Chef cookbooks, Puppet modules, Ansible playbooks), server image building (e.g., Packer), environment provisioning (e.g., Terraform, CloudFormation) and integration of environments. The use of pipelines for infrastructure as code enables errors to be found before changes are applied to operational environments — including environments used for development and testing. They also offer a way to ensure that infrastructure tooling is run consistently, from CI/CD agents, as opposed to being run from individual workstations. Some challenges remain, however, such as the longer feedback loops associated with standing up containers and virtual machines. Still, we've found this to be a valuable technique.Graph QL
column69: One pattern that comes up again and again when building microservice-style architectures is how to handle the aggregation of many resources server-side. In recent years, we've seen the emergence of a number of patterns such as Backend for Frontend (BFF) and tools such as Falcor to address this. Our teams have started using GraphQL for server-side resource aggregation instead. This differs from the usual mode of using GraphQL where clients directly query a GraphQL server. When using this technique, the services continue to expose RESTful APIs but under-the-hood aggregate services use GraphQL resolvers as the implementation for stitching resources from other services. This technique simplifies the internal implementation of aggregate services or BFFs by using GraphQL.Hypermedia
column73: Pattern that enables navigation of clients over REST resources. Clients are not required to know the details of the interface they will access as this is provided at runtime.ULFF
column77: One problem with observability in a highly distributed microservices architecture is the choice between logging everything — and taking up huge amounts of storage space — or randomly sampling logs and potentially missing important events. Recently, we’ve noticed a technique that offers a compromise between these two solutions. Set the log level per request via a parameter passed in through the tracing header. Using a tracing framework, possibly based on the OpenTracing standard, you can pass a correlation id from service to service in a single transaction. You can even inject other data, such as the desired log level, at the initiating transaction and pass it along with the tracing information. This ensures that the additional data collected corresponds to a single user transaction as it flows through the system. This is also a useful technique for debugging, since services might be paused or otherwise modified on a transaction-by-transaction basis.Java
column81: Platform where APIGee runtime is executedKubernetes
column85: Since we last mentioned Kubernetes in the Radar, it has become the default solution for most of our clients when deploying containers into a cluster of machines. The alternatives didn’t capture as much mindshare, and in some cases our clients are even changing their ‘engine’ to Kubernetes. Kubernetes has become the container orchestration platform of choice for major public cloud platforms, including Microsoft's Azure Container Service and Google Cloud (see the GKE blip). And there are many useful products enriching the fast-growing Kubernetes ecosystem. Platforms that try to hide Kubernetes under an abstraction layer, however, have yet to prove themselves.AWS
